reviewText: I made a mistake with this series. I borrowed Volume 4 from a friend of mine to check out the series. It contained the episode where you first meet Legato, a very dark, cruel man who can control what people's bodies, literally. I thought the series was going to be fantastic- a perfect balance between action, a dark plot, and a little comedy.Then I bought the DVD set.I have to admit, I was disappointed by the series. In the first nine episodes, the show appears to be a comedy. Even when the plot becomes more dark with people dying and cities being demolished, the show still tries to be funny. It felt out of place sometimes. The odd looking funny faces also were overdone a little bit.The second half of the show goes more in depth with the plot. But as it turns out, my favorite enemy, Legato, is not the Vash's arch nemesis. That also greatly disappointed me.Other than the show being unbalanced in comedy and in plot development, I found it to be pretty good. There is some pretty good gun action; some episodes have a lot of it while others are a little sparse. I also had quite a few laughs in the beginning with Vash's childlike behavior. I couldn't help falling in love with all the characters since they are full of personality. I'm just sad the show didn't live up to my expectations. It's worth buying the import version of the show even if episode navigation is just as complex as a jigsaw puzzle.

reviewText: The main character of Trigun is an outlaw in a Wild-West-type setting who has superhuman reflexes and accuracy. By itself, this is not particularly new as a premise for an anime. But then, this master gunslinger is shown to be a committed pacifist who refuses to kill, and willingly exposes himself to greater danger in the hope of finding a non-lethal solution.This concept subverts the foundations of an action show. It's especially potent since the show takes Vash's principles very seriously. He genuinely and deeply suffers at the mere thought of having to break his code, yet never wavers in his adherence to it. And he gets pushed very hard, particularly in the second half of the show, where each new conflict makes it more difficult for him to avoid killing. He pays the cost of his choices, too -- his entire body is covered with scars. But he persists.This is very compelling. You are not asked to agree with Vash's philosophy. In fact, most of the other "good" or likable characters either cannot bear the rigour of such a code, or (in the case of anti-hero Nicholas Wolfwood) openly criticize what they perceive as Vash's naivete. Most viewers would probably tend to agree with this more realistic view. But Vash's moral rigour still earns one's admiration, since he bears its full burden. Where most other TV shows and movies try to find excuses for their protagonists to indulge their destructive impulses, Trigun goes for a rise, and makes its hero hold himself to an impossibly high standard.The show also avoids the trap of making the hero seem annoyingly perfect. In the first half of the show, Vash is shown to be a goofball who makes a fool of himself on numerous occasions, and needs guidance from more level-headed characters. Sometimes he acts this way on purpose, to avoid having to argue or fight. But when the show comes back around to Vash's code, it is never less than completely serious.Unfortunately, aside from the premise, much of the show suffers from numerous anime conventions. Most notably, the villains are boring. Vash's arch-nemesis Knives (who came up with this name?) is a cardboard cut-out. The show attempts to give him some back-story to explain his evil, but the explanation is not remotely convincing. He started out normal, was then emotionally abused by one of the crew members (while all the others defended him), and instantly switched to psychotic hatred of all humans. All of his lines thereafter are the usual megalomaniacal rants about how humans are imperfect. Yawn. His minion Legato follows the "effete evil genius" stereotype, with his own trite rants about how everyone is a pawn on a chessboard that he bought and owns. Likemanysuper-villains, he is implausibly brilliant, with the ability to precisely plan his enemy's downfall and anticipate every counter-move. Only at the very end does he get anything interesting to do, when he tries to use Vash's code against him.Trigun also has some problems with pacing. The later episodes have a villain-of-the-week format, where one barely has time to register a new enemy's name, super power, and catch-phrase before the enemy finds a way to die. These episodes also try to cram way too much back-story into a short space of time. To be honest, I don't know that we really needed to know Vash's origin story. He's interesting for how he acts, not where he came from. His fragmented visions of Rem don't really gain any extra pathos after you learn who she is; they might as well have just left them as an unexplained mystery. The gradual shift in focus to Vash's conflict with Knives as the centerpiece of the show also means that the neat Wild-West setting fades into the background. After some time, every new episode has a new town which gets destroyed (or sometimes saved) and then is never heard from again. It might have been better to show Vash as aman-with-no-name(but with a cause), having to deal with the show's lawless world. The more memorable villains are the ones who are vicious, but have mostly recognizable human motivations like greed.The first half of the show is generally more enjoyable (and also lighter). The second half rushes through lots of plot details, but does have one major dramatic payoff in Vash's showdown with Legato. The final battle with Knives is anti-climactic by comparison, since it doesn't tie into Vash's identity in such a powerful way. The writing in the show tends to be very declarative, with the dubbed voices woodenly reciting long speeches, but unfortunately this is another common anime convention, and you sort of have to ignore it if you are going to watch things like this. That sums up the show as a whole -- if you have a high tolerance for anime cliches, you have an easy point of entry, and you can enjoy the truly novel and thought-provoking parts of the show. If not, you might find it more difficult.
summary: Unique protagonist and premise, with some cliches.

Instead,let me address the question that really interests the buyer:is this show worth the money or not?First of all let me agree with some of the other (negative)reviewers: the sophistication of Trigun is nowhere nearthat of Cowboy Bebop. The characters are not deep but they are well written andinteract nicely. It is safe to say that the characters, asalways, are the saving grace of this show. They really manageto keep it going.Unfortunately the show suffers from all the cliches andbad script problems that almost all other animes out theresuffer from. To name a few:1. Excessive use of flashbacks, which show Vash as a littleboy. Well, not as excessive as most other animes, butthey occupy an episode and a half, which is way too much.2. Immature storyline - ok, the storyline is fun, but it'sstill immature. Basically, Vash fights a succession ofbad guys until he reaches the final bad guy. The seriesculminates in a big shoot out. This is typical comic-bookwriting. It works but it's certainly not high level. Youwon't be getting any intense drama.3. Visual humor & slapstick - animes are (in)famous forusing a lot of slapstick. This one isn't an exception.It's not as bad as "man slips on a banana peel" but attimes (not always!) the humor is more "the three stooges"than "Seinfeld" or "Monty Python" or (insert other highlevel humor source here).4. Impossible situations and stupid villians. In one of theepisodes Vash fights a huge giant which shoots out itsfist. Come on, is that for real? The villians are morecomic book villians than real ones. They are alsooften insulting - if you want me to feel a real senseof conflict, bring a real villian. I think I've maturedbeyond "Godzilla" and "King Kong" and I demand that alittle more thought be put into my villians.Nevertheless, the show is not a collection of drivel and lunacy. It has its strong moments. As a whole it can definitely beconsidered entertaining. It's very hard answering the question,"is this worth the money?", because it's impossible to say untilyou've watched the entire series (especially since the bestepisodes are at the end). I'd put it this way: Cowboy Bebop iscertainly the current champion of anime. However, for the 2ndplace (and unfortunately with a considerable distance between the two) Trigun definitely has my vote.

reviewText: Trigun is anime truly unique in its genre. It takes place in the "wild-west" and has hints of comedy and sci-fi. It will definitely catch your attention from episode 1 with its awesome comedy, but this show is sheer brilliance.Vash is not the type of hero or outlaw that we expect him to be. He may seem silly and goofy, but he hides pain and has a purpose and he intends to fix something that had occurred in the past. This is most definitely an anime classic for the way that it catches your attention, makes you laugh, and then gradually reveals a dark and twisted story. This anime gradually makes its way into your heart and forever remains with you. Whether it is the laughs, the awesome-yet ridiculous fight scenes, the characters, or the hidden story, something will remain with you and make you love this show.I highly recommend this show because it is full of so many surprises. Just like Vash himself, this show can fool you with its "silly appearance", but stick around and you will be glad that you did, because it has so much to offer!

reviewText: Trigun hasn't gained much popularity in Japan, but it has a huge following in the US.  Maybe that's because the script writers are using "The seeker of the mayflower of peace" are a commentary about the inherent contradictions in the U.S. culture regarding peace and violence.  The writers accurately catch the fact that most everyone in the "Beautiful Country" (the Chinese characters used to represent the U.S.) is raised Christian, Jewish, Buddhist or other religions that have doctrinal opposition to violence.  Nonetheless, the "Beautiful Country" is frequently involved in conflict, almost in spite of itself.So too, Vash The Humanoid Typhoon, while he wants peace, is constantly located where massive destruction has taken place, and it is never his fault.  He meditates diligently for several seconds, another sly slam on American students who would like to study Asian disciplines like martial arts and yet don't come from a culture that instills them with a prolonged discipline.The beautiful irony in this series is that it is most loved by the people it mocks.  This series catches the inherent contradictions of seeking peace in world which remains uncivil.  It is like the quote from Apocalypse Now, "It was a way we had of dealing with ourselves over here. We cut people in half with a .50 cal and then give them a band-aid for the wound."  Or the soldier in Full Metal Jacket who has a Peace symbol on his helmet.  The Japanese animation directors have written a whole series in homage to U.S. socio-psychological bi-polarism and we love it.This is a marvelous series. Watch it!

reviewText: Trigun is one of those series that gets a lot of lip service from anime fans.  I myself fell subject to that buzz, and made the mistake to purchasing what was purported to be a great anime series.  Imagine my disappointment when I discovered that the misadventures of Vash the Stampede were mindless, poorly written and poorly executed drivel.Don't get me wrong, I tried to like the show, I really did.  In fact, I found the opening episode to be quite strong and interesting.  In it, we are introduced to a man (Vash) called the Humanoid Typhoon, who has been deemed so dangerous that authorities have placed a 60 billion double dollar bounty on his head.  Destruction seems to follow wherever Vash goes despite his best efforts, and miraculously no one has ever died, though cities have been leveled.  The episode is well animated and combines action and humor in a very interesting and entertaining way, so naturally I had high hopes for the series.Then I saw the second episode.  Apparently the entire animation budget was used on the first episode, because the action sequences here have about two frames of animation.  Which would be forgivable if the story wasn't so uninteresting and just downright boring.  But that's alright, not every episode can be great, right?Unfortunately episodes three through seven aren't much better.  Things get slightly more interesting with a two-parter involving a highjacked sandsteamer, but then the show slips back into its slump.  The animation continues to be pathetic and nowhere near as good as other shows from the mid-to-late nineties, and the stories are so poorly written they are almost laughable.  And the endearing klutziness of Vash from the first episode is played up so much that it becomes grating, while the cool hero side of his character all but disappears.About midway through the series, a gang of hitmen called the Gung Ho Guns appears, and their attacks on Vash provide some interesting if shakily executed storylines.  However, thier mindgames with Vash soon wear thin, but all the while I hold out hope that once the much talked about Knives appears things will get better.  Unfortunately, by the time Knives does appear in episode twenty-four or five, the series is far past help.Trigun does have an interesting premise, and the manga its based on is excellent.  However, the anime enscrews all that made the manga entertaining.  The anime severly downplays the action (probably due to budget constraints) while spending far too much time focusing on the more annoying character traits.  Vash as a tortured soul is all but foresaken in favor of Vash the klutz, and the two insurance girls who follow him around are supremely annoying.  The anime also shies away from its source material's darker tone, which contrasted so beautifully with the moments of comedy.  Adding insult to injury, Pioneer insists on selling the box set for the absurb $200 MSRP, a mere forty dollars less than buying the volumes individually.Long story short, the Trigun anime is a case study in wasted potential.  Poor animation and writing coupled with annoying characterizations all but criple the show.  Buy the manga instead, and if you simply MUST see Trigun animated watch the reruns on Cartoon Network late at night.
summary: Well, at Least the Manga is Good...

reviewText: First of all, before I start reviewing this anime, keep in mind that I haven't seen this anime since 2003, so I can't remember every name of every character or some episodes, but I remember enough to have a well-rounded opinion of it.I saw the English-dubbed version of Trigun on Adult Swim seven years ago, and I hated it.  I still hate it now, but my reasoning for it has changed after sitting down and thinking about the anime much deeper than before in recent years.  Concerning the "classic 90's anime," Trigun easily fits within the top 3 in the "most overrated department," along with Neon Genesis Evangelion and Tenchi Muyo.STORYThe story for Trigun is that a mysterious gunman named Vash the Stampede roams a largely desolate planet called Gunsmoke and causes destruction everywhere he goes, even though he doesn't intend to do so.  Vash has a gigantic bounty on his head and lots of bounty hunters, including a psychotic genocidal freak named Knives and his minions named the "Gun-ho Guns" are out to get him.TONAL AND STYLISTIC INCONSISTENCYI'll be frank and say the tonal and stylistic inconsistencies are essentially the "death sentence" for Trigun, because it taints just about every aspect of this anime and makes it so unenjoyable (these faults are also the primary reasons why I hate Neon Genesis Evangelion, but that's another review).  It's like the writers of Trigun couldn't decide between making a cartoonish and light-hearted shoot em' up anime or being a serious action anime with plenty of drama and elaboration of clashing philosophies, so they settled upon the worst option and chose both.  I HATE it when people do this because I watch serious anime to GET AWAY from the comedic stuff.  Mixing serious and comedic tones in anime is like mixing acids with bases, the results are almost always disastrous.PLOTTINGThe plotting in this anime is also victim of the tonal inconsistencies because the anime starts off on the light-hearted, cartoonish side but steadily progresses into something largely serious.  This doesn't sit well with me because I want the tone of a series or movie to be largely consistent and if there is variation, the variation has to be moderate.CHARACTERSContrary to the gobs of gushing reviews, most of the characters aren't works of art.  People everywhere have lauded how "complex" Vash the Stampede's character is.  Yes, in a technical sense, his character is complex, but you have to remember that every quality has its good and bad sides.  Vash's character is very inconsistent, because he'll act like a loud circus clown then out of nowhere, he'll turn into a whiny pacifist who eats doughnuts and constantly bleats "No one has the right to kill another," and in some rare instances, he'll turn into a tough-as-nails gunman who doesn't kill the bad guy at the last minute because he just remembered it was "wrong."  Vash's character is comparable to a dish of cottage cheese, powdered milk, boiled tofu, chicken salad, sweet potatoes, cheap Mexican beer, and chopped liver; they're both complex, but they're certainly not good.  Now, some "contrasting" personalities can add depth to a character's main personality, but those other personalities should be there only to complement the main one and be moderate in tone, NOT to share equal space or overpower the main one because it makes the character look very awkward in an unpleasant way.  An example of Vash's inconsistent personality is in one episode where Vash is on a space station and one of the Gun-ho Guns is aboard as well, gunning down helpless people.  However, there's plenty of scenes with Vash "navigating" through the space station by using his arm-mounted machine gun to shoot giant holes through the space station floors and while he falls, he screams and makes a big dumb face.  Now mixing that loud and dull visual comedy with helpless people being executed like that doesn't sit well with me because it makes the comedic and somber tones feel cheap and undermined.  Another is when a senile midget controlling a giant guy with projectile fists is destroying everything, Vash puts on his "serious" tone and stops the old guy and his living weapon, but after that's done, he starts acting like a clown and starts yelling "The world is made of love and peace" with a bunch of kids.  Hand me a barf bag.  In previous years, I loathed Vash's pacifist philosophy just because he refused to kill people, but that's largely changed now.  The protagonist doesn't have to kill every bad guy in order to gain my personal approval now, but the fact that Vash is constantly harping about his beliefs pushes me to the other side and makes me want to jump into the Trigun universe and subject all the bad guys to the same treatment Isaac Clarke dishes out to the Necromorphs in Dead Space just to horribly spite Vash.  After some mental re-evaluation on certain plot points in Trigun, I was screaming to myself in one of Vash's "killing people is wrong" speeches "ALRIGHT, WE GET IT!!  SHUT UP!!"  It doesn't help that in the English dub, Vash is voiced by Johnny Yong Bosche, who has one of the most unpleasant and whiny voices I've ever heard in any medium.  Some characters like Wolfwood and Knives are actually pretty interesting because they largely maintain a consistent tone (and thankfully, they're more on the serious side), but the consistent characters are unfortunately, less in abundance compared to the inconsistent ones.  Meryll Stryfe and Millie Thompson weren't terribly impressive characters because they seemed like all too conventional cutouts of the "George and Lenny" dynamic in the John Steinbeck classic Of Mice and Men, other than the occasional moments of Meryll screaming her head off in a comedic style (these moments aren't funny to begin with).THEMESThere's some potentially good themes in Trigun about the clashing philosophies between Vash and Knives since the former doesn't believe anyone should be killed, while the latter believes in something closer to eugenics as to where all the "weak and stupid" should be killed so the superior creatures can live in a "better world."  I also like how in one flashback episode where Vash and Knives are kids, Vash sees a spider web with a moth being stuck on it and a spider getting ready to eat it, but Knives kills the spider.  Vash protests and says he should have saved the moth instead, but Knives's justification is pretty interesting because it was pretty legitimate, which was "If I save the moth, the spider will starve."  Sadly, these themes are undermined by the well-established tonal inconsistencies.APPEARANCEThe animation and artwork is actually pretty good, and it shows another quality product from Madhouse Studio (only speaking about production).  The animation is pretty smooth and the artwork is nicely detailed, though I'd say this is one of Madhouse's lower-quality products (along with that overrated saccharine pukefest Chobits and the ever-so-worthless Devil May Cry).  However, more inconsistencies lay in here as well.  Vash makes really goofy exaggerated faces throughout the series (along with many other characters), such as when Vash defeats the main bad guy in the first episode, he makes a cat face when he says something like "Some toys are fun, but you can get hurt."  Also, for an anime with villains that do pretty terrible things, some of the villains' appearances undermine the grim moments since they look like something ripped out of Power Rangers (yuck).SOUNDTRACKThe soundtrack is okay, I guess, nothing special.  I honestly don't remember much of it other than some Western-sounding acoustic guitar riffs and some riffing more on the electric and funky side.  I wasn't impressed the last time I heard Trigun's music, but the music wasn't anything offensive, so I guess that's a plus.FINAL WORDWhile Trigun isn't nearly as bad as say, Elfen Lied or Fullmetal Alchemist, it's still a really wretched title.  Trigun is a classic case of "what could have been."  Had this anime maintained a serious tone and focused on the clashing philosophies of Vash and Knives and didn't waste time with gobs of redundant comedic filler, this could have been the "great" anime that legions of people are hailing it as.  If you like comedy mixed with serious tones, then you may like this.  However, if you're like me and HATE mixing the two, skip Trigun since you won't get anything out if it that you can get from numerous other titles that are much superior.  If you want some decent light-hearted/comedic anime, go get yourself some Devil Hunter Yokho and Excel Saga (at least they both maintain consistency).  I suggest you go watch Perfect Blue, Battle Angel, Neo-Tokyo, Shigurui:  Death Frenzy, Jin-Roh, and Ghost in the Shell for some quality "mature" anime.
summary: One of the best anime titles ever?  Ha!!  21%

reviewText: I've heard it argued that there are better animes out there. This statement is probably true to a degree if we want to get into art and intrensic deep meaning and symbolism, but for animes that are just enjoyable to watch and poignient when they need to be, Trigun is one of the best.Vash the Stampede is a wanted criminal. Wanted for a lot of money for supposedly doing a lot of crimes. Two insurance agents, Meryle and Milly do their best to catch up with the outlaw, but when they do, they realize that Vash is a bit of a goof ball who not only hates bloodshed, but has never even killed anyone and refuses to kill even animals. Added to the mix is Wolfwood, a hedonistic priest with a painfully sketchy past. There is a lot of humor, but there are also truly painful moments.Vash is a unique anime male in the fact that he IS a bit of a goof and he's also sensitive. Vash cries more than any other male anime character I remember watching, yet he still comes out strong. He's got a big heart and seems to feel everyone elses' pain personally.If you want art for art's sake, don't bother, Trigun isn't a masterpiece of anime in that sense. reviewText: I have a feeling people are going to hate this review because of this anime's reputation, but I'd like to remind everyone that this is an opinion, and if you love Trigun or it's your favorite anime of all time, that's not wrong - it just means you like different things than I do.Now that I've got my flame shield up, I'll say that there's nothing wrong with Trigun at first glance. The art style is great, the music is great, a lot of the characters are great, most fight scenes are pretty great - but here's the problem: the main character and inconsistent tone.Trigun is an anime that doesn't seem to know what it wants to be half the time. Other anime have rapid switches from serious to jokey, but they usually know when it's time to just be serious or awesome; Trigun does not. In the middle of a serious scene, the main character, Vash, will suddenly freak out and run around in terror, while the other characters roll their eyes. This happens without fail, and it ruins many of its own moments by not respecting the tone it had set up. In some places it works, but in others the balance is completely off and it feels more schizophrenic than anything.The overall story is very patchwork; individual, smaller storylines are often uninteresting or entirely random, but the history of the main character and the world in general are far more interesting and engaging. I found the story ultimately unsatisfying, but only because of the inconsistent tone.Throughout Trigun I was constantly alternating between excited and irritated, and in the end irritation won out and left me with a negative view of the series as a whole. Obviously many people feel differently, so don't take my opinion as gospel. Trigun is absolutely worth a shot, but try before you buy - hopefully you'll be like one of its many fans and discover something you can love, but there's always the chance you'll be like me - disappointed at something you -could- have loved being consistently ruined by out-of-place tonal shifts.

reviewText: It's amazing seeing how well Trigun has aged since it aired on Cartoon Network in 2003. I've always thought about picking it up on DVD but have found most anime sets are charging $80 or more for an entire series. While this boxed set is cheaper than most and includes every episode it's lack of extras will put off people who're looking for collector's editions.Trigun is based off the manga series by Yasuhiro Nightow taking place in a sort of western/sci-fi universe (sort of Mad Max meets Firefly). Vash the Stampede is a light-hearted, somewhat aloof marksmen who has a $60,000,000,000 price on his head. Trouble seems to follow him everywhere and not only because of his bounty. Despite his gun-skills, Vash is a pacifist and tries to get out of situations in the most non-violent manner he can. Through his adventures Vash meets Meryl and Milly, insurance agents investigating claims against Vash and the destruction he causes. They also meet up with Wolfwood, a priest with gun-skills equal to Vash's own. While on the surface these characters seem like typical anime-types, each one carries a certain emotional weight with them and we learn more and more about each of them as the series progresses. This somber tone flows through each episode (even the more wacky ones) and really sets this show apart from most other anime's out there.If there was any flaw with this series it probably comes from the abrupt shift in pacing in the later episodes. The first episodes play out like we're following one long road-trip and one big story-arch. Later the episodes shift with flashbacks and jump-forwards and they start to lose their continuity. You will still able to figure out what's going on but for me this was sort of jarring to the experience (especially trying to watch all the episodes in one sitting).Like I said before, this boxed set of Trigun has little extras so if you already own the series there is no reason to pick up this package. There are four discs with all 26 episodes meaning there are six or seven episodes crammed onto one disc at a time. This leaves little room for extras and the video quality might not be up to standard (it looked fine and cleaned up on my 20" tube television but I can't vouch for anything bigger).If you don't own the series already and are like me and just looking for all the episodes (without spending too much $$$) then this Trigun Boxed set is perfect for you. Even if you're just an anime or sci-fi adventure fan looking for a fun show with a refreshing twist I'd recommend giving this set a shot. It's got likeable chracters, fun action scenes, and mixes humor with seriousness without too much of either. A must-see experience!

reviewText: Trigun is without a doubt one of my favorite anime shows ever. The protagonist Vash the Stampede is extremely endearing and instantly likeable. On the oustide, he appears to be a goofy clutz who is incapable of doing anything, but when things get serious, he instatntly transforms into a flawless hero. At first, there are only glimpses of the potential Vash has, but later on, his tragic past and true abilities are revealed in full.At first, we are led to believe that Vash is a terrible monster who leaves a wake of destruction in his path wherever he goes. From the beginning, all the viewer sees are allusions to the "Humanoid Typhoon." Yet, we learn that Vash refuses to kill fairly early on. Slowly, his past is revealed such as how he lost the one woman he cared for most, had a growing rift with his psychotic brother Knives (the antagonist), and felt pain and alone when there was destruction which he did in fact create, but against his own will and self control (you will see). Vash is often forced to carry on with a heavy heart. He is a true hero in every sense of the word.The first few episodes are very light hearted and watching them in retrospect makes them seem all the more poignant. There is a distinct parallel between Rurouni Kenshin and Vash. Vash refuses to kill others although he has the power to destroy entire cities lying dormant within him. However, one reviewer stated Vash should be more like Kenshin from Samurai X. I question whether this person ever saw the Rurouni Kenshin TV series which took place well after the Samurai X OVA. Just like Vash, Kenshin refused to kill as well. He regretted nearly EVERY action that he took during the OVA time frame and prior to it.That being said, Trigun is not a show that revolves completely around action, although there is a fair bit involved in the show, especially once the "priest" Wolfwood comes into play. Instead, the show relies on charm, wit, humor, drama, and most importantly of all, the development of the characters in order to unfold its story. Don't be misled into thinking that Trigun is a mindless action/violence based anime, nothing could be further from the truth. Vash is forced to kill one time in this series and the agony he goes through over that one moment is striking. There are definetly messages which are trying to be sent across throughout this show.The side characters in this show are also nicely developed. There's Meryl and Milly. Meryl and Milly constantly follow Vash, at the urging of their insurance company. They hound him throughout, and vow to monitor every action that he takes. Meryl is clearly the leader of the two, but she completely misunderstands Vash initially. However, as the show goes on, she begins to understand him more and more, and realizes the pain that he has been forced to harbor for so long. Milly is the silly bumbling sidekick who always looks lost and confused. However, she belies a deep sense of intuition and abilities within her which even surprise her. In fact, if she could just realize it for herself, she's just as capable if not more so than Meryl. The pair can grow tiresome at first, but after a while, they become far more solid characters who do little to detract from the plot.This brings me to my favorite side character, the "priest" Wolfwood. Wolfwood is an amazing compliment to Vash. He's the man on a mission who can't be stopped. The "cross" which Wolfwood carries on his back is actually a weapon that fires powerful, furious, shots. He is the blunt, rebel type, character who defies what everyone around him says and lives only for himself. Or so it seems. Yet, like Vash, Wolfwood has been forced to harbor terrible amounts of pain. He's also the one who saved Vash from himself and brought him back to reality when he became disillusioned. (when Vash becomes "Erik") In fact, in my opinion, the saddest moment of all during the show revolved around Wolfwood. Wolfwood was in tears, and the viewer will more often than not nearly be too...The band of  villains in this show were all interesting and fairly unique. I wish their pasts could have been developed more, but that's just a minor gripe. The fan favorite of the villains is Lagato Bluesummers and he is indeed a powerful character. The confrontation between Vash and Lagato is one of the most powerful moments of the show. And of course there is Knives, the evil half if you will of Vash. They are brothers and look similar to each other, but that's about all the similarities that they share.In the end, Trigun was a magnificent ride of 26 episodes. I bought the box set here on amazon over a couple years ago, and it was 180$, so apparently there has been a 30$ reduction in price. All the more reason to buy this box set ^_^. This series has my strongest reccomendation as it is my second favorite series of all time. Trust me when I say I have seen a lot of anime. As Vash would say, it's all about "love and peace." And of course, doughnuts.

reviewText: TRIGUN is without a doubt one of the most original and spectacular anime series that I have ever seen. After watching all 26 episodes, I can assure you that purchasing the box set is the farthest thing from a waste of money.As many people can tell you, the story centers around Vash the Stampede, a legendary 'outlaw' who leaves a wake of mass destruction in the towns he passes through (though no one ever dies, not a fact to be overlooked). After receiving several hundred claims on "Humanoid Typhoon"-related events, the Berardinelli Insurance Society sends two claims investigators (the no-nonsense Meryl and her ditzy yet insightful partner Milly) to find this Vash and stop him from causing any further damage. After searching for rumors of this 'terrible' man, they can't believe it when they meet the real thing - instead of a cold-blooded killer, Vash is one of the most hilarious and crazy people on the planet.The first 12 or so episodes of the series are mainly individual-episode stories that focus on humor and character development, with the introduction of such memorable characters as Kuroneko-sama (the mysterious black cat) and Nicholas D. Wolfwood, the traveling priest with the biggest "cross" you've ever seen, and a host of strange villains and ordinary people who cross Vash's path. It's hard to believe it when in later episodes, the humor slowly dies down and Trigun reveals the dark drama that left me in tears for the last few episodes.This series defies a genre - while it is a sci-fi/western story, labels such as "shoujo" (girl's story) or "shounen" (boy's story) simply do not fit - EVERYONE I know loves this show, whether they're teenage girls or middle-aged men. The animation quality is consistently excellent, the music is a perfect fit (especially "H.T.", the opening theme), and you're guaranteed plenty of laughter (especially when Vash is around pretty women) and tears (episode 23 reduced me to a sobbing mess).Love and peace, and of course donuts for all. ^_-
summary: Any fan of animation, humor, and a great story will love it.

reviewText: He's prone to whining, crying and throwing tantrums, but Vash still manages to get the job done!  Since I was introduced to Cowboy Bebop a little over a year ago, I've seen many different Anime, and I have to say flat out that Trigun is my favorite.  Ironic, considering that Vash the Stampede is the epitome of everything I couldn't stand about Anime before I became a fan, but I actually find Vash to be completely hysterical, and one my favorite anime characters.Its Wild West meets futuristic Sci-Fi in this anime about a man with names like 'The Humanoid Typhoon' and 'The 60 Billion Double Dollar Man'.  Beleived to be the cause of mass destruction wherever he goes, Vash is actually a misunderstood, friendly and peace-loving individual...who is armed to the teeth, with superhuman strength and speed, the sharpest eye on the planet, and a 60 Billion Double Dollar bounty on his head that many are just itching to get their hands on.  He hates violence and won't bring himself to kill anyone...and he has his reasons.The overall plot of the show is great, but only loosely follows the Manga, since the anime is very different towards the end.  Every episode is a continuation in the overall story.  The first few episodes are mostly comical, but as the series progresses, Vash's true enemies reveal themselves and the show begins taking a darker tone.  Many revelations about Vash's mysterious origins are revealed, and at about the middle of the show there is an origin episode that explains it a bit moe.  That said, this anime is both completely hysterical and filled with great action.  Vash's ridiculous behavior, stupid facial expressions and whining and screaming add a whole dimension to the character.  Half the time when I watched this show, I was laughing.  Sometimes it was so funny I was doubled over and tearing from the comedy aspect.Side characters Meryl and Millie are also good characters...Millie's rather stupid but resourceful personality make her one of the funniest characters on the show (and one of my favorites).  A gun-toting priest priest known as Nicholas D. Wolfwood shows up, inadvertantly forming a friendship and partnership with Vash, which leads to more hysterical situations.  When the main cast of villains begin to get introduced to the show, it really takes off.  Some of these villains, namely Legato Bluesummers (one of my all time favorite anime characters), are among the most sinister and evil characters I've seen yet in Anime.Trigun happens to be my favorite Anime.  The overall series has its fair share of comedy, alot of action, but also alot of emotion, particularly towards the end of the show.  Combined with great character development, excellent animation, and a very good soundtrack, Trigun stands as one of the best anime to come out in recent years.  As the second anime I got into after Bebop, I found it to be very entertaining and easy to get into.  While the manga differs a bit from the anime, Trigun is definitely a great show and is worth the watch for any anime fan.  Chances are that if you liked Bebop, you'll like Trigun.
summary: Hysterical and action-packed...a great anime series!

reviewText: Trigun is, without a second doubt, one of the best animes ever released. The writing is excellent, the animation is charming, the pacing is top notch, and the conclusion is poignant. In my honest opinion, there are few better animes out there greater for the purpose of exposing somebody to Japanese anime. Probability is that if they don't like Trigun, for whatever reason, then they probably won't enjoy anything else...although this will be difficult, because Trigun is incredibly difficult to dislike, let alone hate.Trigun tells the story of Vash the stampede, a gunman with an absolutely enormous bounty on his head. Vash's reputation as the most famous and deadly gunman in the world is well known, and everywhere he goes trouble always follows. His reputation of completely destroying entire cities and towns has earned him the name "The Humanoid Typhoon", and he is universally feared and hunted as the world's most notorious outlaw.The only catch is that, in reality, Vash is not at all what his reputation makes him out to be. Vash is actually a bit of a goofball, who really only seems to be interested in eating and flirting with beautiful women. Vash's tendency to hide his dark side with humorous antics masks the truly serious nature of his being, and even though he is a good hearted spaz, there is truly a dangerous side to him as well. Throughout most of the series, Vash is uncharacteristically passive, and we quickly learn that it is often those hunting him down that are the ones responsible for the destruction he seems to leave in his wake. Nevertheless, one must never underestimate Vash...who is actually far more powerful than even his reputation leads people to believe.Vash is an exceptionally well written character, and even though he's really the glue who holds the show together, his companions and enemies are just as interesting as he is. Vash quickly makes friends with a couple of girls from an insurance agency hired to follow Vash and record his activities, and he later also befriends a no-nonsense priest-slash-gunman. Another great element to Trigun is Vash's rogue's gallery...a long list of villains who range from psychopathic murdering machines to more sympathetic foes. I'd say that all these characters make the show notable for having side characters who are just as memorable as Vash himself.The complete series of Trigun ran alongside Cowboy Bebop on Cartoon Network's Adult Swim entertainment block for a long time, and for many Americans it was this, as well as Toonami, that introduced us to anime. If you're even casually interested in anime, you owe yourself to watch this, and this collection is just fine.The english dub is actually pretty good, fortunately. Lots of animes botch their translations into english, but that's not really the case here.
summary: Trigun is one of the most excellent animes ever, and a highly recommended series for introducing someone to Japanese animation.

reviewText: Warning: Contains spoilersI recently read a review of Trigun by a Christian lady who wrote that the protagonist, Vash the Stampede, reminded her of Jesus Christ. I understand this. Trigun is an anime series and might be dismissed by people who think it's "just a cartoon." There's no denying that Vash is a goofy guy, obsessed with donuts and prone to acting like a lovesick teenager whenever he sees a pretty girl. The first few episodes are silly beyond belief-or are they?The series is only 26 episodes, and as it progresses, it quickly becomes evident that the way Vash acts is just that-an act. He has an almost unbearably tragic past and it has left him with a firm determination never to kill and an overwhelming desire to protect the innocent. His idiotic grin is conciously used to hide behind-a fact that characters comment on from time to time. His true self is much more serious.Trigun poses the tough questions. Vash wants more than anything to save people. He wants everyone to live together in peace and happiness. He suffers for his convictions, his body terribly scarred, his soul oppressed with grief and pain as he is forced to come to the realization that it is not always possible to protect an innocent person without taking the life of a guilty person. His anguish when he is forced to kill one villain to save two helpless women is overwhelming.It begs the question-how far does one take pacifism? Is it even possible to be a pacifist in this imperfect world? How does one reconcile a belief in the sacredness of life with the pure evil that some people spread through their lives, and how does one stop an evil person without killing them? Is mercy to the guilty injustice to the innocent? These are the questions Vash wrestles with and there are no easy answers, nor does Trigun provide a happy ending. In fact, the finale is rather troubling, with Vash once again attempting what seems an impossible task-the redemption of his brother, a merciless killer, yet a man he loves and is not willing to give up on.Trigun is not a show for children, although Vash is one of the most visually striking characters in anime and there's a lot of exciting action. There's also a lot of death, including the death of children, one of whom is shot when he is about to kill Vash. It's an intellectually demanding show that takes the viewer, not to some grey area between good and evil, but right up to the razor's edge in the middle of the grey area, where morals and values cease to be words and become worth dying for and one step over the line becomes a burden that can never be lifted.There is a heavy Christian influence in Trigun. Aside from Vash's mantra "Thou shalt not kill" there is the priest, Wolfwood, who not only kills but bitterly quarrels with Vash over the necessity of killing. He's seen Vash's scars, mental and physical, and he doesn't believe in the ideals that Vash tries to live up to. Yet in the end, he comes around to Vash's point of view. In fact, there are a number of people, good and bad and indifferent, whose lives are turned around by Vash. His willingness to suffer so that others may be spared has an extraordinary effect on those he comes into contact with. However, Trigun doesn't pull any punches. Vash's desire to keep his own hands clean sometimes leads to terrible consequences. He's not all-powerful and sometimes his pacifism costs more lives than it saves. Yet somehow he never loses faith that he can find the answer to the impossible questions his pacifism raises. When he is finally forced to kill, he is sure that he could have found an alternative that would have allowed everyone to live. And he agonizes more over the death of one murderous criminal than that criminal did over the deaths of hundreds of innocent people.In the end, Vash seems to find some balance in his life, an awareness that it is not always possible to save everyone. At the same time, he does not lose his faith in the belief that everyone is worthy of being saved, nor does he lose his hope that if he tries hard enough, he can find the answers to the tough questions. Trigun rewards rewatching, the early silliness having an almost unbearable poignancy as the viewer remembers all the pain and sorrow Vash is hiding with his buffoon act. It's impossible to view this show in a thoughtful manner without pondering the problems Vash is facing, and trying to find some answers for oneself. And the lady who found Vash reminding her of Jesus Christ? I understand. While Vash isn't Christ, he is an example of how a person can find redemption in following the ideals of Jesus. Perhaps "Thou shalt not kill" is an impossible standard, especially in life and death situations, and perhaps it is foolish to believe that everyone can be saved. It's still good to watch something like Trigun, a story that advances the thought that impossible standards are worth trying to live up to.

reviewText: Meryl and Milly are two insurance agents with a mission: find Vash The Stampede, a man with a $$60 billion bounty on his head, and stop him from causing any more damage! With a bounty that big and followed by a wake of destruction, Vash must be big, intimidating, and down right scary! Right? To Meryl's constant aggravation and disbelief, Vash turns out to be a friendly, doughnut loving pacifist. Its hard to believe that he has survived this long! But there is more to Vash then meets the eye, and the series starts to turn dark as Vash's past is brought to light.This is a very entertaining series. The first half is mostly comedic Western style short stories, i.e. Bad guy threatens people and Vash bumbles his way in and saves the day with his amazing gun skills. Vash is one of the best anime characters I've seen and it is lots of fun to watch him save the day. The guy that shares the cover with him is Nicholas Wolfwood, and the two of them are excellent foils to each other. Around episode 15, things start heating up as the story starts focusing more on Vash's mysterious past.I normally watch anime in Japanese, but when a dub is truly impressive I make an exception. This was one of those dubs. Johnny Yong Bosch does an awesome job as Vash, and all of the rest of the cast does a good job as well.Trigun is one of my favorite anime series, one I recommend to just about anyone, be they anime fans or not! This release looks good too - with 26 episodes on 4 discs, it doesn't take up too much shelf space. reviewText: Trigun is a good anime series, but I would not say it is one of the best of all time.  The story takes place on a desert planet with a western backdrop, and revolves around Vash "The Stampede," a lone gunman with exceptional, inhuman marksmanship.  At first he is seen as childish and a coward, but in later episodes he reveals a deeper, darker more intense side of himself.  He lives by the philosophy that it is not right to kill no matter how much power you possess.  And Vash does have power.  It is this way of thinking that inevitably causes him much pain and suffering thoroughout his life, especially since almost everyone is out to kill or capture Vash for his enormous bounty (60 billion double dollars) or for some other reason.I noticed there are many reviewers who think this series is garbage, particularly since Vash refuses to kill.  To all of you idiots I ask, "If someone who possessed the kind of power and skill like Vash has spent the entire series slaughtering all his enemies, what would that contribute to the series as a whole?"  The answer is simple.  It would contribute absolutely nothing.  It would make the series hollow, stupid and pointless...just like many of your critiscisms.  I suppose there will always be some people out there who are to dumb to realize the emotional depth of the Trigun series.  These are the same people who bash the Evangelion series as well, and quite frankly, your stupidity makes me sick to my stomach.There are several reasons why I could not give 5-out-of-5 for this series.  For example, even though Vash's character development was fairly good the story failed to answer essential questions such as, "What is Vash?"  And, "Where did he learn his incredible shooting skills?"  "Where did he come from?"  Also, the two supporting female characters Millie and Meryl had almost no character development whatsoever.  This is odd because they are two of the main characters, and yet the viewer knows almost nothing about them except that Millie is...well...kinda dumb and Meryl has about as much warmth as a winter afternoon.  Nicholas Wolfwood is an interesting character.  He is a "priest" with surprising skill as a marksman.  He seems to be the only real supporting character in the series, and the only one who actually cares for and understands Vash.All in all, Trigun is good but not great.  The animation is not the best and the music throughout the episodes could be more interesting and varied.  The extras are mediocre with nothing special to offer.  The story itself makes up for most of the series' shortcomings, but not all.  It has some loose ends and potholes, but in my opinion it is still worth watching.  I liked Trigun, and I think it is a decent, if not excellent, piece of work.  Everyone has different tastes, and you'll either like it, love it or hate it.  At the very least give it a shot, even if it is just volume one, and then judge for yourself.
summary: A Good Story, but Lacking in Other Areas.

reviewText: Trigun is essentially Rurouni Kenshin with guns. I believe that is the best way to describe it. The similarities are quite striking - the hero protects people with weapons, which are, by definition, designed to injure, maim and kill. Also like Kenshin, Trigun mixes action and drama with comedy, although its transition from serious drama to light-hearted comedy works much better than in Kenshin, in my view.However, where Kenshin tells the story of man's triumph over adversity (the worst that happens is Kenshin turning to the Battousai without actually killing anyone, due to luck or other factors), Trigun actually takes that a step further and shows the effect of the guilt on Vash, when he 'crosses the line'. This is shown very well in his confrontation with Legato later on in the series.Trigun has a reputation of having filler episodes throughout its beginning, but if filler is defined as a 'one episode storyline', then the entire series (this applies to other series as well) is simply a 10-hour lump of filler. Episodes that do not advance the primary plot do not bother me, but an excessive amount of them can ruin the experience. More important than advancing the plot is making the viewing experience enjoyable. Ghost in the Shell is an example of where this failed to happen for me.The only real flaw I can find with Trigun is that some of the characters are not as well developed as Vash, Wolfwood, Knives or even Frank Marlon. If we learnt more about Milly, Meryl and some more of the Gung-Ho Guns. Despite this, Trigun is one of the best action-adventure animes around, and is highly recommended for fans of the genre. Even those not into action will find something to like in Trigun.

reviewText: "Trigun" is another one of those anime that I have known about forever, but never got around to watching for some reason.  At almost any manga/anime convention you are guaranteed to see at least one Vash the Stampede walking around with Nicholas D. Wolfwood carrying a giant homemade cross. When Funimation put out this boxset of the Complete Series, I figured it was finally time to sit down and see what all the fuss was about with the guy in the long red coat and his friend with the giant cross.To no ones surprise, "Trigun" is a great series.I really love the Space Western genre (Firefly, anyone?) and "Trigun" takes the tropes of the genre and gives it some unique twists.  Sure, there are the usual drifting into a barren town and kicking out the local boss, or quick-draw contests and bank robberies, but there are also sentient plants and seedships traveling interstellar distances.Tone-wise, the series is split almost directly in half.  The first part is a screwball comedy of errors, focusing on two insurance agents Meryl and Milly, as they hung for the legendary gunfighter Vash the Stampede, known as the Human Typhoon.  Vash causes enormous amounts of damage every where he goes, and the insurance company is looking to cap their loses.  They fall into company with a goofy, seemingly harmless guy in a long red coat who (of course) turns out to be Vash the Stampede himself.  But instead of a cold, calculating gunman Vash is a pacifist who fights only for Peach and Love and refuses to kill.  They do some road tripping, moving from town to town, and pick up as a straggler the priest Nicholas D. Wolfwood who turns out to be almost as good with a gun as Vash himself.The second half get serious, delving into the past of Vash and Nicholas, and the mysterious killer known only as Knives.  Vash has a history that he has entirely forgotton, including exactly who and what he is.  And it turns out that Nicholas did not join their company by accident, and tragedy moves in his wake.I confess I like the second half better than the first.  The "super killer who is really a nice guy but just misundertood" bit works for awhile, but starts to wear thin.  And just when you can't take another comedy of misunderstandings and hijinks, the true story takes over and you delve beneath the surface of the characters.  That was were this anime moved from just mindless fun to something worthwhile and interesting.I am glad I finally got around to watching "Trigun."  Great series, and this Funimation boxset is an economical way to get all 26 episodes.  There isn't much here bonus feature-wise, but that isn't really necessary.  The story is complete as it is.
